NewsDetail.Name: 01-05-11 Business Simulation
NewsDetail.Title: Students introduce business simulation at middle school
NewsDetail.Abstract: Four BYU-Idaho students shared their passion for entrepreneurship and education with fifth graders when they introduced a business simulation program at Madison Middle School.
NewsDetail.Author: Writer: Brady Davies
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Four Brigham Young University-Idaho students and their adviser, Jason Earl, shared their passion for entrepreneurship and education with fifth graders when they introduced a business simulation program at Madison Middle School.

The Collegiate Entrepreneurs Organization (CEO) members taught business principles before letting students try the simulation program Robo-Rush. The game-like program was originally developed for a Master of Business Administration program at Acton School of Business in Austin, Texas.  However, the 10- and 11-year-olds were not intimidated by the game, which covers door-to-door sales, opening a store, and building a factory. “Even though the game is used in an MBA program, we thought it was simple enough for the kids to enjoy,” said Michael Ross, a student CEO member.

After the instruction, the children were able to practice the business principles they learned. One child said, “It works better to use the employees because it goes much faster.” Another commented, “Popular does not always get you a profit.

Universities across the country are beginning to use simulations to educate their students. Simulations allow students to practice what they are taught and see the results of their decisions. “Had we just presented the business ideas in a lecture, there is no way the kids could have comprehended it,” said Tyson Poulton, a student CEO member. “If you take the simulation away, you take away their learning opportunity.”

The university students’ commitment to spread entrepreneurial practices may also benefit other Madison County schools soon. BYU-Idaho student Andrew Walker said, “We plan to run this simulation with several other elementary and middle schools on a regular basis to help them better understand entrepreneurship and the business world.”
